projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

Full documentation of the original data capture process is available from the Text Creation Partnership web site. All versions of the texts are now archived and freely available for download. See the TCP Download FAQ for detailed information. The TEI P5 versions are also freely available from the TCP Github repository.

figure.figDesc: royal blazon surmounted by a crown and flanked by the English lion and Tudor rose on one side and the Scottish unicorn and thistle on the other

div.head: BY THE Lords-Justices AND COUNCIL. A PROCLAMATION.
div.p:
WHereas by the Examinations of divers Persons We find that a Romish Priest, calling himself Father Chr • stopher Browne, who has lived many Months in several Places in Their Majesties Power (and especially at the House of John Common of Godamendy, lately Executed) without being molested upon the account of his Orders or Religion has been, if not the first Contriver and Principal Director and Conductor, yet a main Abettor and Encourager of the late Barbarous Murder of many of Their Majesties Soldiers in Mallahuddert Church near this City. And whereas it appears likewise that Nathaniel Moore of Notts-Town, commonly called and known by the Name of Natty Moor, William Lawrence, late Servant to Bartholomew Ward of Tyrrills-Town, commonly called and known by the name of Billy Lawrence, Nicholas Strong of Ballicoolan, Bartholomew Clinch of Kilmartin, and Thomas Dillon Brother to Martin Dillon of Hunts-Town, are also Guilty of committing the said Barbarous Murther, and that they and every of them being Conscious thereof, have withdrawn themselves from Iustice: We do therefore Authorize and Require all Officers Civil and Military, and all other Their Majesties Loving Subjects, to Apprehend and Secure the Bodies of the said Christopher Browne, Nathaniel or Natty Moore, William or Billy Lawrence, Nicholas Strong, Bartholomew Clinch and Thomas Dillon, and every or any of them, and them, every or any of them to cause to be Committed to the County Goal, where they or any of them shall be Apprehended, so as they may be brought to Iustice. And for the Encouragement of such
as shall endeavour to Apprehend all or any of the said Persons: We do promise in manner following. First, That such Person (not being Guilty of the said Murther and Treason, or of being aiding and assisting therein) who shall Apprehend and Secure the said Christopher Browne, or cause him to be Apprehended or Secured, so as he may be brought to Iustice, shall have and be paid the Summ of Fifty Pounds; and to such as shall Apprehend and Secure the aforesaid Nathaniel Moore, William Lawrence, Nicholas Strong, Bartholomew Clinch and Thomas Dillon, for each and every of them the Summ of Ten Pounds, to be paid them out of Their Majesties Treasury; and to such other Person or Persons, tho' Privy to the said Murther and Treason, who shall Apprehend and Secure the said Christopher Browne, Nathaniel Moore, William Lawrence, Christopher Strong, Bartholomew Clinch and Thomas Dillon or any of them, or cause them or any of them to be Apprehended and Secured, so as they may be brought to Iustice, an Assurance of his or their Life and Liberty. And We do hereby further Publish and Declare, that if any Person or Persons living in any Place or Places under Their Majesties Obedience, shall at any time hereafter presume to Receive, Harbour, Comfort, Relieve or Conceal the said Christopher Browne, Nathaniel Moore, William Lawrence, Nicholas Strong, Bartholomew Clinch and Thomas Dillon, or any of them, or shall hold any Correspondence with them or any of them; they and every Person so Offending, shall be Prosecuted with the utmost Rigour, and Punished as Aiders Abetters and Correspondents of Traytors, Murderers, and Enemies to Their Majesties and Their Government.
div.closer:
Given at the Council-Chamber in Dublin the 15th day of April, 1691. and in the Third Year of Their Majesties Reign.
Fran. Dublin,
Longford,
Anth. Midensis,
R. Fitz. Gerald.
Char. Meredith,
J. Hely.
God Save the King and Queen.

div.p: Dublin, Printed by Andrew Crook Assignee of Benjamin Tooke Printer to the King and Queen at Their Majesties Printing-house on Ormonde-Key.
